global_flags.description: Forced mode: doesn't check if the keys are present on  the  re‐ mote server.  This means that it does not need the private key. Of course, this can result in more than one copy of the key be‐ ing installed on the remote system.

only  the  key(s)  contained in identity_file (rather than looking   for   identities   via   ssh-add(1)   or    in    the default_ID_file).  If the filename does not end in .pub this is added.   If  the  filename  is  omitted, the default_ID_file is used.
do  a dry-run.  Instead of installing keys on the remote system simply prints the key(s) that would have been installed.
through  untouched,  along with  their  argument,  to  allow  one to set the port or other ssh(1) options, respectively.

SFTP mode: usually the public keys are installed  by  executing commands  on  the  remote  side.   With  this option the user's ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file will be  downloaded,  modified  lo‐ cally  and  uploaded  with  sftp.  This option is useful if the server has restrictions on commands which can be  used  on  the remote side.
path  on  the target system where the keys should be added (defaults to ".ssh/authorized_keys")
This option is for debugging the ssh-copy-id script itself.  It sets the shell's -x flag, so that you can see the commands  be‐ ing run.
